column4: I can't tell completely your issue, but make sure ifconfig -a shows all of the devices, and you may want to look at /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules
Thank you, ifconfig -a does show all devices
what if you do sudo ifup eth1
It says that interface eht1 already configured.
are they the same mac address, or different?
so you can't ping the ip address you set from within /etc/network/interfaces for eth1 or eth2?  maybe try uninstalling network-manager if it's installed
I can ping the IP address that is assigned to the adapter from the Ubuntu box itself.
so 192.168.1.0 / 24 works but the others don't?
Yes. Only things of note are that it was the first interface configured during setup and the only interface that has a default gateway defined.
are you sure the other two NICs are bridged properly in Hyper-V?  Make sure they are External and not Internal or Private
Yes, I am sure they are connected to the proper external network with the proper 802.1Q tag associated with them.
have you tried running /etc/init.d/networking restart or restarting the server?
